Description: Copper alloy leaf shaped arrow-head with a mid rib ending with socket and tang.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

These leaf shaped, socketed and barbed types appear to originate in Anatolia and the Ionian cities of western Turkey. This example has good parallels from the mid-7th to 5th centuries BC (Baitinger 2001, figs 98-111, Zweiflügelige Tüllenpfeilspitzen type IIA2). Parallels from Tell Dafana and the nearby site of T21 that Oren identifies as ‘Migdol’ (Snodgrass 1964, 151, double edged with spur Form 3A2 dated to before c.600 to 460 BC; Erdmann 1973, 45 Form DIIc3, dated to 8th- 4th BC, or possibly longer date range; Oren 1984, 25, fig. 26.3 dated to late 7th to 6th centuries BC). For a discussion of provenance see also Pelleg et al. 1983. Baitinger, H. 2001, Die Angriffswaffen aus Olympia, Berlin & New York. Erdmann, E. 1973. ‘Die sogenannten Marathonpfeilspitzen in Karlsruhe’, Archäologischer Anzeiger 88, 30-58. Forsdyke E. J. 1919/20, ‘Some arrow-heads from the battlefield of Marathon’, Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of London 2.32, 146-157. Oren, E. D. 1984, ‘Migdol: A New Fortress on the Edge of the Eastern Nile Delta’, Bulletin of the American Schools of Oriental Research 256, 7-44. Pelleg, J., Baram, J. and Oren, E. D. 1983, ‘Analysis of bronze arrowheads of the Saite period from the Nile Delta region’, Metallography 16.1, 81-98. Snodgrass, A. M. 1964, Early Greek armour and weapons from the end of the Bronze Age to 600 BC, Edinburgh. Snodgrass, A. M. 1967, Arms and armour of the Greeks, London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (SB.12) (Phase 2)
